description.text: this is my first attempt at a 3D printable object. It's based on a design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9710#) I saw at my friend's house. It is a single print that has moving parts. This has now been updated to have much better tolerances between the wheel and the wheel-well. Enjoy :D

Note: I've uploaded a new file that should fix the issue that slic3r was having (resulting in only half the car printing) also, smoothed for better wheel rotation. VRRROOOM!
I printed this to be about 4 inches long on the longest side, at that scale the tolerance around the wheels work great! You could probably print it smaller (as long as your printer is well calibrated) or bigger and it would be fine.

title: Quarter Turn 5 Dollar Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
Quarter turn Spool Holder for ProtoParadigm's five dollar filament

UPDATE
I just added a new version of the male flange called "undersized". Some people have no issues but some say the detents are too tight. The undersized flange detents are .02"(.5mm) smaller then the original, so If you print the original and have issues with the detents breaking off then print the undersized male flange instead. Let me know which one works best?
Or try the threaded version it is more forgiving. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2086521

UPDATE 4/3/17
I added a spool flange with only a 98mm OD per request so it can be printed on a 100mm bed.

This is a revision of my original spool holder for ProtoParadigm's five dollar filament which is used to stabilize the spool while printing. The previous version required one and a half turns to thread the flanges together. I wanted a quicker way to assemble it, so I came up with this version that utilizes ball detents instead of threads so only a quarter turn is required to assemble the flanges.

42mm ID x 115mm OD flange

author: piodoi

title: Cura Plugin - Dual Optimizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Last Updated: v1.3 (Mar 4, 2017)

This is a Cura plugin designed for dual extrusion 3D printers
[Tested on Cura 15.04.6]
Features:

  1. Swap the extruders only when necessary to save your time.
  2. Print only the walls of the "prime tower" when the extruders are not to exchange.
  3. Trim the used top layers of the "prime tower" when there are no further swaps. [optional]
  4. Force to swap the extruders without changing filament spools. [optional]
  5. Force to use either extruder #0 or extruder #1 without changing filament spools. [optional]
  6. Scrubbing nozzle by specified extruders with individual counts, distance, retraction and extrusion speeds. [optional]
    • Note: This is an experiment feature and could likely grind the filament.
      Specifying the count of scrubbing with the extruder can make it to clean up the residues of previous filament from nozzle. However, repeated retraction and extrusion on the same position of filament could make it ground.
    • With zero scrubbing distance, the retraction distance will be automatically applied.
    • Retraction speed of scrubbing will reference the travel speed if it is set to zero.
    • Extrusion speed of scrubbing will use the "normal" retraction speed if it is set to zero.

Change Log:

  • v1.1:
    1. Fix bugs about identifying the file positions and bounding coordinates of prime tower when any of the following options is set:
      • "Support dual extrusion" => "Second extruder"
      • "Platform adhesion type" => "Raft"
      • "Support" > "Structure Type" => "Lines"
    2. [Experiment] Scrub the nozzle by retracting and extruding for specified times to clean the residues of previous filament.
  • v1.2:
    1. Refine the nozzle scrubbing feature with the parameters: Retraction speed and extrusion speed of Scrubbing.
  • v1.3:
    1. Move the tool head over the prime tower while swapping the filament in order to prevent the print from being oozed or melted by nozzle

title: HTC Vive Mount HMD + Controllers + charging
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are extra parts to turn my HTC Vive HMD Wall Mount Lite and HTC Vive controller wall mount and charging station into a full all-in-one wall mount for the HTC Vive that needs only 3 screws to fasten instead of 6.

The above parts can be used separately of course but then each would need 2 screws to be mounted correctly and being in a rental apartment I'd rather make as few holes as possible. So I came up with this design where a central "bridge" can connect the 3 parts providing some stability to prevent the parts from rotating while using only a single screw for each.

You'll need to print the bridge and 4 clips.

NB: the bridge part isn't particularly strong, don't expect it to hold up if used carelessly.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The bridge printed perfectly in PLA using Prusa's default NORMAL settings (with ZHop).

The clips really need to be printed at .20 I think otherwise they won't fir correctly.

Printer model: Prusa MK2 (but that doesn't appear in the list)

After printing the bridge insert the 4 clips into the slots in the four ends.

Then I'd suggest to first mount the HDM bracket on the wall using just a single screw in the center (don't forget to lead the USB cables through the slots in the back, you won't be able to do so once mounted). Fasten lightly so the bracket can still rotate somewhat with a bit of force. (See second photo)

Then insert the bridge on top of the bracket, again making sure the USB cables are guided through the slots in its back. Make sure the HMD bracket is as level. (See third photo)

Now carefully connect one of the controller mounts to the bridge by sliding the clip on the bridge's arm into the slot in the side of the controller mount's back plate. Don't use a lot of force because the bridge isn't very strong (just strong enough to prevent the parts from rotating, it doesn't need to carry any weight). Mark the place of the controller mount's top mounting hole on the wall, remove the controller mount again and drill a hole. Now reattach the mount to the bridge and fasten it to lightly the wall.

Do the same for the other controller mount. Now tighten the 3 mounting screws (taking care not to break the plastic). (See fourth photo)

print_settings.Notes:: roof needs supports

description.text:
Printer:

kossel delta XL 20/20

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

roof needs supports

We'd bought some beautiful pens as Christmas presents for family, but wanted a novel way to package them.  I designed this screw top tube which is pretty and functional (and long term re-usable - which is more than can be said for most wrapping paper).

This case is 16cm long and can hold a pen no longer than 14cm.  It does scale well (as I found when I realized one of the pens had a wider diameter) but ensure you scale both lid and body otherwise you will have problems with the threads.

Uses:

  • Standard Stake bearings 608zz (22mm OD / 8mm ID / 7mm Thick)
  • Metric M8 Nuts

Printing as is, without any scaling, should be fine and be tight enough for the nuts to not come out. If they are too tight a hammer would work as it did for me. Please tell me what you think and if they are any problems.

Happy printing :)
Please like and share.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

print_settings.Notes:: Tested with ABS.

description.text:
There are other clips on thingiverse however they seem to either require a lot of support material (and clean-up) or are too thin in critical areas which is why your clip probably failed in the first place...

This clip suits snorkels with a round tube, though it is possible for it to work on a slightly oval-shaped tube. The clip for the straps is also customisable for different strap widths and thicknesses.

The included STL is suited for a 27mm diameter snorkel but may fit others of slightly different sizes without modification.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Tested with ABS.

There are two small pillars that act as support for the overhanging part of the clip. These need to be cut out and is easily done with some sidecutters. If these are not removed then it will be difficult (or impossible in some cases) to attach the clip to the mask strap.

title: CTC Silhouette Messerhalter Schneideplotter / Silhouette Cutting Blade Holder

description.text:
Ich verwende zum erzeugen des Gcodes Inkskape und das JTech Laser Plugin. Dieses habe ich umprogrammiert um eine "Overcut-Funktion" zu ermöglichen, welche vorher nicht verfügbar war. Die neue Version, welche perfekt auf den CTC abgestimmt ist, ist im Downloadbereich hier bei Thingiverse dabei. Nachdem wir den Gcode ausgegeben haben, muss er von dem Format .gcode in .X3g umgewandelt werden um ihn von der SD-Karte abrufen zu können, dazu verwende ich hier ReplicatorG. Hier muss man aufpassen welche Version man benötigt, da manche ihren Drucker, so wie ich, auf Sailfish geupdatet haben. Nach dem umwandeln kann man die Daten auf die SD-Karte packen und sie von dort aus direkt mit dem Drucker Plotten.

Um starten zu können benötigen wir erst einiges an Vorbereitung. Als erstes alle Teile drucken, welche dazu benötigt werden. Ebenso alle Dateien unten aus den Links downloaden und installieren. Ebenso kann gleich die Silhouette Klinge (12€) und die PVC Folie bei Amazon oder ähnlichem bestellt werden. Ich habe mir am Anfang ein Farbset gekauft um eine Grundauswahl zu haben, jedoch kann ich nach einiger Erfahrung sagen das man aber meist nur Weiße PVC Folie und die Trägerfolie benutzt. Ebenso benötigen wir einen Schutz für das Druckbett aus Kunstststoff, welche ich mir im nächsten Baumarkt geholt hebe und sie mir dort gleich auf 250mm x 180mm x 3mm zurechtschneiden habe lassen. Ebenso benötigen wir eine Feder, welche ich mir gleich im Baumarkt mitbesorgt habe. Wer diese aber lieber bestellen will, für den ist ein Link zu einem Federset unten in den Links vorhanden, da das Federset in Baumärkten ca. 20€ kostet. Mein Baumarkt des Vertrauens hatte die Federn jedoch auch einzeln verkauft. Die Feder hat die Maße 9mm x 35mm und wurde von mir auf 40 mm aufgezogen.

Das Messer
https://www.amazon.de/Silhouette-SILH-BLADE-3-3T-Replacement-Holder-schwarz/dp/B005S2O61E/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1480682347&sr=8-2&keywords=silhouette

Die Folien
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Folie-12-x-DIN-A4-Klebefolie-Plotterfolie-diverse-Bogen-Blatt-BUNT-Vinylfolie-/222361095744?hash=item33c5c10e40:g:C0QAAOSwPcJVR3c3

Inkskape
https://inkscape.org/de/herunterladen/windows-installer/

Replicator G mit Sailfish
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32084/#files

Replicator G ohne Sailfish
http://replicat.org/download

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

60%

Gedruckt in ABS mit 40mm/sek bei geschlossenenm Bauraum und 110° C Bett Temperatur sowie 235°C Extrudertemperatur.

author: Freeman9144

description.text: Simple and closed filament guide for Anet A8.

title: Eachine E010S / Tiny Whoop / EF-02 Camera Mount (10 Degrees)

description.text:
Pretty basic 10deg camera mount for the E010S & EF-02.

The arms will bend when you screw them down because there are a bunch of caps and stupid crap in the way, but it should be fine.

I put a bit of blue-tac in the center to fully keep the camera in place.

Most other camera mounts are incompatible because the E010S has a button and antenna at the front.

UPDATE:

I made a couple of changes and pushed the camera back a bit. Still over a bunch of dumb caps but it's more central than before.

comments.text: Good job, nice and compact; just one thing, the holes for the screws are about a mm too close, it pulled my frame to a slight bend until i drilled them a bit larger to fit without the tension.
comments.author: Denes

comments.text: Had a friend print one of these for me on his printer. Fits the e010s well and with an elastic band put over the top holds the stock camera nicely. Thanks for the contribution!
comments.author: B1ondeange1

comments.text: Thanks for this! Fits great on my e010s with stock camera setup!

description.text:
Remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833104 by xxricsxx with 3-point levelling of the heatbed from CBiker (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746345)

[UPDATED VERSION ]

back_V2.stl - fixing of the back screws no longer dependent on legth of cross profiles.

Other parts used:

  • 2x Cap_20x20.stl
  • all parts from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833104 by xxricsxx
  • Druckbett_3Punkt_Leveling_1.stl (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746345/#files) by CBiker
  • adjustable Z-Endstop (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054110) by Willefg

The endstop for the z-axis has to be relocated.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Das Wichtigste auf Deutsch nochmal:

Remix von xxricsxx's Alutisch (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833104) mit der 3-Punkt-Lagerung von CBiker (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746345)

[NEUE VERSION]

back_V2.stl - hintere Heatbedbefestigung nicht mehr abhängig vom Längsprofilabstand

Ich habe alles in PLA gedruckt, aber wer vor hat irgendwann auch mal was mit höheren Temperaturen im geschlossenen Gehäuse zu drucken sollte lieber ABS nehmen.

Sonstige verwendete Teile:

  • 2x Cap_20x20.stl
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833104 (Betthalter nur 1x und Verstellung nur 3x)
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746345 (Nur Teil 1)
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054110

Der Endschalter für die Z-Achse muss versetzt werden.

Vielen Dank an xxricsxx, CBiker und Willefg für die Inspiration! :-D

PARALLEL JAW OFFSET GRIPPER
Two gear racks and a pinion open and close the gripper jaws by rotating a handle connected to the pinion. 180 degrees of rotation opens the grippers 1.5".

Required Fasteners:
To assembly the gripper base.
(2X) M3 x 10mm Lg. Socket Head Cap Screws
(2X)- M3 Hex Nuts

To mount the tooling to the gear racksracks. (optional)
(4X) M3 x 10mm Lg. Socket Head Cap Screws
(4X)- M3 Hex Nuts
Note: A set of gripper tooling is provided but additional tooling made for your application can be mounted utilizing the M3 mounting nuts inserted into the gear racks.

The updated version will operate with a stand hobby servo.

title: Retro Playstation Pi Micro USB Power Outlet

description.text:
Scope

This is a microusb power outlet for the original Playstation 1 case.

About

I was building a Playstation Pi Retro console, but wanted to use a micro usb power adapter instead. Therefore I designed this outlet to hold the corresponding micro usb adapter. It fits the playstation casing perfectly.

Different Versions

Version 1:
  • Usb cable holder only
Version 2:
  • Usb cable holder + some overhang for the circuit board from the Playstation Pi Retro console project. Use this, if you are using the step down converter from this project.

Additional parts

I used the following micro-usb cable as inlay for this part:

  • StarTech 0,5 m, Micro-USB

author: dexter620

description.text:
This is a coin holder designed to fit into a car cup holder. It's customizable so you can select whatever coins you need to organize in your car. The coins are spring loaded, so they're always easy to get to.
So far I have dimensions for all common US and Euro coins. If you need other coins added, let me know. I need the diameter and the thickness of each coin to add them.
Fixed a bug that caused the springs that were displayed in preview to be in the part to print.
  • Added Australian coins (for cursed dagger).
  • Added Canadian coins (for jonnyroy)

Parts

  • I have a set of parts attached, for US coins (dollar, quarter, dime, nickel, penny) for a cup holder 3" across and 2" deep. You can print them, or make one customized for you.
    To create a coin holder, you will need:

  • A cup holder. You already have this. You'll need to know its diameter, and depth.
  • Compression springs for the coin slots. You'll need to know the spring's diameter, and it's compressed length. The spring has to be taller than the depth of the cup holder when uncompressed, so that the plungers are pressed up even when empty.
    The coin holder consists of the following parts:
  • The coin holder body.
  • The plungers, one for each coin slot.
  • The cover, that holds everything together.
    Customize

  • Open this in Customizer, and:

    1. Enter the spring and cup holder measurements.
    2. Select the number of coin slots that you want.
      3, For each slot, select the specific coin.
      Print the parts, I generate a 'plated' version with one STL with all of the parts, which should fit on a large bed printer such as a Replicator. Or you can print the body, cover, and plungers separately, which should fit on any 3D printer.
      The coin slots all fit for me printing in PLA. If you print on ABS, you might want to scale everything up by 2% (in your printer software) to compensate for the shrinkage. Though I'm not sure that 2% will matter.
      Assembly
    1. Put the springs into the plungers
    2. Put the plungers into the body. This is easiest if the body is on its side, so the springs don't slide out. Slide the plungers in and out a few times until they move freely.
    3. Put the cover on top of the body. There is a "key" on top of the body which should fit into the hole in the cover. Make sure that the cover is aligned properly with the body (and not upside down), then glue it down.
      Use

  • To put a coin into the coin holder, slide it into the slot on the side. Press the plunger (and coins stacked on it) down to allow the new coin to slide in.
    To remove a coin from the holder, just slide it out out the same slot.

title: 3D printer case with Lack tables (Ikea)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is parts to build a 3D printer case with Lack tables from Ikea.

Edit: To regulate temperature within the case, you can use two 12V fan and a w1209 for example, that's what i will do. Here is a w1209 case i made too.

After printing parts, you need:

  • 2 or 3 Lack table from Ikea
  • 4 x acrylic glass (plexiglass) 4mm (0.157") thin 50cm x 44.5cm (19.68" x 17.52")
  • Wood screws and hex screws

While mounting the plexiglass panels, you will have to cut a little piece in plexi to fit with top links. It's normal and easy to do with a jigsaw (or handsaw).

For those who want to use plexiglass of different thickness than 4mm, here is the files (only the files that change, you still have to download the master folder):

  • Box with 2mm thickness plexiglass
  • Box with 3mm thickness plexiglass
  • Box with 5mm thickness plexiglass

Note: The L_shape.stl is to join the first table from floor and the second together. Rods of plastic are here to center the L without mesuring, cut them when you found their good place :)

Printer:

Dagoma DiscoEasy200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

There is no need of supports for all parts exept the door knob.

Infill of 30% is good as parts need strengh exept the door knob that can have a 10% infill.

For the hinge, print them upside down to avoid supports !
The L_Shape (plastic rods already cut)

description.text:
This is an adjustable webcam stand for a Raspberry Pi 2 (B+) or 3 based webcam. It has a holder for the Pi and a mount for the Pi Camera (v2).

There are three printed parts required:

  • Webcam base: the stand and main holder
  • Camera frame: a frame that goes around the camera and attaches it to the base
  • Pi bumper: a frame that goes around the Pi and attaches it to the base

In addition, you need two pieces of electronics (three if you want it to be accessble over a wireless network)

  • A Raspberry Pi B+, 2 or 3 - I used a B+ for this project and it was more than capable of handling the load.
    https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/model-b-plus/
  • A Raspberry Pi Camera or NoIR Camera module: https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/camera-module-v2/
    https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/pi-noir-camera-v2/
  • (Optional) A USB wireless receiver for the Pi. I used a PAUD6 from Panda Wireless, which is totally overkill for this project but works well.

Assembly:
Attach the Pi Cam to the camera frame using either M2 fasteners + nuts or small zip ties. Attach the Raspberry Pi to the base, securing it with the Pi bumper. Depending on the tolerances of your printer a small amount of glue may be required (if the holes are too large for a friction fit).
Secure the Pi Cam mount to the base using a short piece of 3mm filament from your printer. If you use 1.75mm filament you can wind some scotch tape around it to thicken it up appropriately.

Software:
I used the following software for this project:

  • Raspbian Jesse Lite
    A lightweight, well supported distribution for the Raspberry Pi 2 and 3. Since this is a 'headless' setup (no monitor, keyboard or mouse) there is no need for the graphical interface, hence the 'Lite' version.
    https://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads/raspbian/

  • RPi-Cam-Web-Interface
    A set of configuration files that will guide you through the setup of webserver to display the output of the Pi Cam. Allows for essentially real-time viewing, with a variety of options on the website to take pictures, record video, enable motion-triggered events, etc.
    http://elinux.org/RPi-Cam-Web-Interface

Change Log:
v1: Initial Release (all files without version numbers)
v1.1: corrected tolerances on the camera frame + pi bumper part. Added tabs to the pi bumper to make it easier to ziptie.
v2: significantly reduced use of zipties and size of webcam base. Added printable bolts to adjust camera angle. Split Rpi holder and base so that improvements can be made without reprinting base part.

Future work:

  • stiffer/better camera angle (with screw or some other variable friction method)
  • better pins for the PI and camera holders to eliminate the need for fasteners/zipties

Ultimaker

This project was modeled in Onshape, link to the project is below:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/31d4017e2e6f70f146dbaa5c/w/2eafcf1239804d4739245e5b/e/34fa523e12e1ad99b153b2da

For those of you without a Onshape account I've included .STEP files of the components that you can edit/change as needed. If you are willing to create an account with OnShape (which as of this writing is free) you can export the project in a variety of file formats.

Credit to OnShape users 'ihsan berk güneytepe' and 'Jan Rychter' for the use of their Raspberry Pi and Pi Camera models, respectively.
This is the last Diamond of the collection. Now all four are ready.

Fusion 360

Add image as canvas, and sketch over it. Extrude sections as desired.

comments.text: This is great.  I have been looking everywhere for this. By chance did you create the other pieces?
comments.author: TCSmith

comments.text: I actually did make the rest of it, but it isn't an exact replica of the old parts. the old clip probly wouldn't fit into the new part. Plus I haven't tried printing the other part, so I don't know how accurate it is also as the original is made of aluminium. I guess you could still print it up. But again the original clip probly wouldn't fit. Unless you make your own clip.
comments.author: TCSmith

comments.text: What I was planning on doing was working on it a bit to make an attachment for my bike and car.  I would just need the other end that attaches to the clip in order to do so.  I was getting ready to do all of the work when I found your post and figured i should ask.
comments.author: Wadoman1

comments.text: I uploaded the rest of it. Let me know if there are any issues with the parts fitting together as I haven't tested that part for fit. Also keep me posted on how your part comes out
comments.author: TCSmith

comments.text: Ok, so I have printed all of the pieces and here are a few things.  The base clip and the clip are a tight fit.  I had to use a hammer to connect them but it fit and it is in the snug.  So for me I think the fit is fine.  Once I attached both pieces to the phone I realized that the holes in the back of the base are slightly off center.  Again this is not a big deal for what I plan on using it for.  Lastly, the tongue it noting more than one or two layers of plastic.  I think that I might use it on some sheet metal as a template and then bend the metal to my needs.
comments.author: Wadoman1

comments.text: Well thank you for getting back to me after your test prints. I knew it would be a tight fit as I intended the main base piece to be machined from aluminum like the original instead of 3D printed. The tongue piece was never shaped(bent) as it was intended to be like you said a template for sheet metal. As for the holes, if I remember correctly they are as close as I could get to matching the original. And just so it's clear the original tongue will not fit into this.
comments.author: TCSmith

comments.text: no problem i think what this is amazing and i can work with it.

title: Redesigned Z-stage support for Vertex K8400
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are two problems with the way the original K8400 Z-stage is designed.

  1. The whole Z-stage is resting on the coupler between the motor and the leadscrew. This coupler then acts as a spring and can be compressed by ~0.5mm just by pushing on the leadscrew with a finger. I see this a lot in 3D-printers and it's just bad practice. The coupler is just there for misalignment between the leadscrew and the motor axle, NOT to actually take any load in axial direction.

  2. Because there are individual holders for the linear bearings, it's very easy to misalign them resulting in high friction and maybe even choppy movement with cheap bearings. This is enhanced by the springiness of the motor coupler, because if the bearing is stuck the coupler will just stretch and then jump resulting in uneven layer heights.

My solution:

  1. I designed a new motor mount for the Z-Stage which includes a pillow bearing (for example: Miniatur Flanschlager 8mm) There is still room under the motor and three of the original mounting holes can be used. I drilled two more to have more stability. The whole Z-stage now rests on the pillow bearing which has no flex resulting in very even layer heights.

  2. I just connected two of the original bearing clamps in vertical direction so that no misalignment is possible here. In addition I used high quality linear bearings (Misumi) as the originals are not very good.

Additional hardware needed:

  • 1 countersunk M5x10 screw with nut (lenght not critical)
  • 2 M5x12 screws + nuts for the pillow bearing
  • Pillow bearing for 8mm rods/leadscrews.

Preparing the pillow bearing:
Those cheap pillow bearings are stuck in the housing at first, but they are supposed to swivel to compensate for misalignment. You have to brake them loose by force, take them out and polish the mating surfaces by adding metal polish, pop the bearing back in and move it around. Repeat until smooth then add grease

Assembly:

  1. Mount the motor to the motor mount
  2. Attach it to the Vertex rear panel. The top screw on the right has to be the countersunk screw.
  3. Add the coupler.
  4. Pillow bearing (you will curse a lot)
  5. Add the leadscrew.
  6. Drink a beer

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The linear bearing mounts should be printed in 100% infill. I tried 50%, but they cracked as there is quite a lot of stress on these parts, when they compress around the linear bearings.

The motor mount could be printed in 50%. I wouldn't go with less as the whole Z-stage is resting on this part, so I printed it @100% infill.

comments.text: I uploaded an updated version with a bit more bracing around the motor mount. As for layer delamination, my set I printed in ABS had similar issues. I ended up printing at 235c with flow set at 104%. That seemed to do the trick with layer bonding. Also, I kept the fan speed down to 40%.

comments.text: Why not use Luer lock nozzles, saves you from printing that adapter and ruining expensive metal nozzles. Also wondering why you use the syringes original plunger, why not have the threaded rod push the directly on the rubber plunger? You could design a small part onto which the rubber fits and into the other side goes the threaded rod. Saves you a lot of height.
comments.author: unfold

comments.text: I am using the luer lock now. I didn't have tips when I designed this. Changing the plunger style is on the agenda, just haven't had time. Thanks for the feedback though. I've followed your work and love it.
comments.author: unfold

comments.text: Thanks for the kind words theshort. I just cobbled together a mix of your upper drive mechanism and my 60cc syringe cap for air pressure. It's not pretty at all but hope it gets the job done to test. Trying to put it together today, will upload a derivative if I have more pictures. Not entirely sure how you had the bearings and gear installed. Did you use washers somewhere? My gear is super tight so I might need to redo it.
comments.author: theshort

comments.text: Are you referring to the fit of the large gear between the split halves? I used a stock Printrbot extruder gear with with a 5/16" (8mm) nut inserted. It will only fit one way with washers. Its designed so when the back pressure from the plunger pushes the nut up into the gear and then transfers that to a washer and 608 bearing. If I remember right the nut side of the gear is down. Hope this helps.
comments.author: unfold

comments.text: Yes, that part, I printed it as one piece with support since I did not understand how they were supposed to be assembled. I looked at the Printrbot gear and printed a herringbone gear based on that but I can barely fit it in with the two ball bearings. I figured that the back pressure would push everything up so only using a top bearing now with washer. Bit wobbly, can always print a bit lower profile gear in order to fit the second bearing. Looks promising but will see tomorrow when I actually try to push clay, will keep you posted!
comments.author: theshort

comments.text: I've added some photos of it assembled to help.
comments.author: unfold

comments.text: The two pieces glue together. Its very strong. Yeah if you don't use the gear with the same tolerances I imagine it wouldn't fit right. Let me know how you fair.
comments.author: unfold

comments.text: Do I recognize the Printrbot Small and Large gears :) I like it.
comments.author: abdrumm

comments.text: Awww, just the person I need to ask. Yes, you do recognize them. What is the gear ratio? I figured it was about 4:1? I'm hoping the torque produced by this little guy will be enough to extrude clay.

title: MPCNC 4pin stepper plug for X/Y rail upgrade mod

description.text:
This set contains endplugs for X/Y axis tubes as well as new guard for the belt.

I created it because disassembling of MPCNC took me so many hours since steppers were hardwired. Plugs enable you to use 4pin plugs (or 5 or 6 or whatever) to wire steppers. The belt guard needed to be redesigned so I changed it as well.

I designed these for use with INTERNATIONAL EDITION i.e. 25mm outside diameter with 2mm wall thickness.

comments.text: How much belt clearance is there?
comments.author: gadgetmind

comments.text: Almost nonexistent on the part with cable, protruding one, but I cannot feel any friction. On the shallow part there is no collision since the protrusion is shallower than the belt line. I will probably update design on weekend to make more space for belt, probably will end up with one v2 part for both ends.
comments.author: gadgetmind

comments.text: That would be good to see. I've been playing in OpenSCAD and for me a 45 degree angle on the end prints better and 22mm for the socket section, rising to 24.5mm for a 2mm flange to engage with the tube end works better, but I'm still printing and tweaking. I wasn't going to bother with aviation connectors but the idea is growing on me.
comments.author: modularis

title: Low profile anti wobble / anti backlash system for prusa / logresse

description.text:
remix of thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162647 by tonymtsai which is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:141479 by jamesarm97.

This remix provides the same functionality in a low profile form so the hotend can be mounted higher on the x-axis which improves stability while printing and results in great printing quality improvements. Best printed with 100% infill as your x-carriage has to be supported by this. Total height is 13mm instead of 23mm for the one from tonymtsai. Another 2mm could be shaved off if the bottom mutter is trimmed by 2mm. A spring has to be added below the top mutter for the anti backlash to work properly and the top mutter may not stick out of the part.
Feel free to use/modify it to your needs.

title: IKEA Billy door pull drill guide

description.text:
The IKEA Billy bookcase 203.238.05 comes with a wooden "knob" to open the doors. I found this neither ergonomic nor aesthetically pleasing, so I wanted to replace it with a brushed satin drawer pull. The drawer pull I'm using is 3" (76mm) on center) for the screws. This drill guide should locate off of the pre-drilled hole for centering, and provide properly spaced holes for the new handle.

This piece is relatively thick to help keep the drill bit square with the door. The guide pin is tapered to make it easy to insert into the hole, and the alignment tabs have a draft on them to make it easier to get onto the door, and for some added strength.

The drill bushings are sleeved, with a taper towards the door. This should mean that the typical forces on them from the drill bill will tend to pull the piece together, rather than tear it apart.

title: How to upgrade your Asus Xtion into a beautiful 3D scanner

description.text:
At le FabShop, we've been using the Asus Xtion and Kinect a lot for scanning people and large objects (Skanect is our favourite tool for that). None of these objects is ergonomic. Instead of just creating an other handle for the Xtion, we decided to transform it into a professionnal looking tool. le FabShop's handle is designed to be confortable, while solving a few other problems. An other awesome design from our creative designer Samuel N. Bernier -It keeps a 45 degrees axis for the scan to be oriented easy
-the USB cable is hidden inside the handle, so it isn't in the way
-The base is large enough, so the scanner can balance on itself
-the base is copying the shape of manfrotto's classic plate for entry level tripods.
-If you own a different type of tripod, you can still screw your plate in the handle by using the hole at the bottom
  • We also designed a lense protector that clips around the sensor, for safe transportation.
    • We found the Kinect a little bit ennoying to cary with us on events and presentations. We were also quite disapointed by the performance of the Sense from 3D System, wich isn't bad, but just not better than what we already had. Combined with Skanect, the ASUS Xtion is a great scanning tool. Be careful of one detail. If you want color on your 3D file, you got to purchase the Xtion pro LIVE, not just the Xtion pro. Only the LIVE version has the camera that captures the colors. In total, expect to pay 300 dollars for tour DIY 3D scanner. You can see some results of our scans here : https://sketchfab.com/lefabshop/recent If you are in europe, you can also order the Xtion on the FabStore : http://www.lefabshop.fr/fabstore/fr/36-outils-3d

So, it's pretty eassy. All you got ot do is print the handle and the protector in ABS or PLA, as you wish. Take the Xtion and remove carefully the plastic caps on the axis. Use a philips screwdriver to remove the screw and the plastic component holding the axis. Carreful, the nut on the other side will fall off. Replace the flat base with the handle and do the steps backward... you are done! Start scanning. To use with a tripod, there is a hole for that :)

I made a Raspberry Pi home assistant (kind of like Amazon's Alexa) using all open source, self contained software (So I wouldn't need an internet connection). I named it Cogsworth and I programmed him so that he had several hundred possible responses to various things such as being addressed and being asked to check the weather etc... Almost all of those responses were rude and snarky.

In making Cogsworth's body, I had a few goals to keep in mind:

  1. keep it compact. (small printer, with very limited filament)
  2. make it possible to fasten him to a flat surface.
  3. make it look like he isn't terribly thrilled to be helping you

For goal 1, I had to start over several times, as I kept making him too big. I kept tying to make the Pi housing his chest, and that led to much bigger robots. Moving the Pi housing to his face helped a lot, and allowed me to make sure that all of his ports were accessible.

For goal 2, I made his feet long and forked so that a screw can be threaded between his 'toes' to fasten him to a desk/wall/ceiling

For goal 3, I gave him a flat-topped eye based roughly on 80's robots like ultraman or tranformers (I had just read Ready Player One at the time of designing). I also placed his face directly in front of his body and rounded his shoulders to give the impression that he is slouching.

My prints were fairly rushed, so the quality in the photos aren't fantastic.

If you have any questions, please feel free to ask!

title: 3mm MDF Lasercut Miniature Slotta Base Assortment

description.text:
MDF 25mm or 1" slotta bases that I assembled to use as space fillers for my lasercut projects. Produces plenty of bases per sheet with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. Some slots are centered and some are offset and measure 21mm x 2mm, which is what I measured off a collection of plastic slotta bases. Sheet contains a mix of hex, round and square slotta basing.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 12" x 9" (Arch A sheet size) - four of these would fit within an (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size or across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. title: Instant Wingnut Adapter M3 M4 M5 M6 M8 M10

description.text:
Ever needed to loosen a bolt or nut in an almost impossible place?
Or needed actually TWO wrenches to have a grip on both sides of a bolt&nut when you only have one wrench for a certain nut size?

Here is a simple and easy to make solution.
With these Instant Wingnut adapters, you can turn any normal M3 to M10 bolt or head into a wingnut and apply force with your hands.
Just print the wingnuts you need and drop them in your toolbox.
Or even just leave them in place near your heating radiator, plumbing or wherever you might need a quick and easy way to loosen a bolt or nut.

These wingnuts were designed by me in OpenSCAD.
I have included the .SCAD-file in case you need to adjust the measurements for your particular application. The wingnuts work best if they are a tight fit.

Mankati Fullscale XT/XT-Plus

QX08 Family of Pegs

This is another entry into my growing PEGBOARD MADNESS collection of designs. There are more designs being worked out, so come back later!

These pegs are variations on existing Pegboard Hooks and accessories as can be found in industrial catalogs. These are BEEFY objects, and can withstand moderate to heavier levels of use! The bodies of these components consist of an 8-sided polygon circumscribed on a 4.5mm diameter circle swept along a path.

I have included STEP files of the objects so that you can easily import them into most cad programs and modify/adapt or create innovative storage solutions that you can use and contribute to the 3D community.

NOTE: Using the Octagon Profile provides better strength and wear than a Rectangular Profile, but doesn’t require supports during the build that a Circle Profile would require.

NOTE: See my QX09 family that uses these pegs  http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121956

FILES:

QX08a Simple Hook: This is your basic hook. It prints in 7 minutes. Great place to start out. You may want to add to the infill% or Shells for certain applications requiring greater strength.

QX08b VersaDaptor – Two Posts : This is a funny looking device I designed to be a central component to future designs. For example, it can support two levels of shelving! Check out my QX09 family to see one use.

QX08c VersaDaptor – Post & Hook: Somewhat like the QX08b, except it provides ONE post for shelving, and a hook underneath for hanging other objects.

These Peg STL’s were sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 1 shell (2 total) and 10% Infill using PLA.
No rafts or supports!

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius (Heated Bed not required, but I have good luck with a little warmth!)
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

REQUEST: Please help me improve my sharing! STEP files have proven reliable for me to transport file between different CAD platforms. If STEPs are a problem for you, please let me know what other common and relatively generic Cad format works better for you.

ADDS:
02/19/17 __ QX08d VersaDaptor Rod/Post/Hook: Sports an extended Rod to hold larger shelf (See the QX09d Shelf v1 in “QX09” family)

title: Lens hood for Zoom Q2n Handy Video Recorder

description.text:
The Zoom Q2n Handy Video Recorder is a compact video camera optimized for high-quality live audio recording. It has a couple of recognized shortcomings: 1) mediocre battery life - which this thing won't help, and 2) high susceptibility to lens flare even under routine lighting situations - which this thing was designed to help alleviate.

At present, you can buy a lens hood from Zoom only as part of an accessory kit. It seems like an okay kit if you really want all the pieces, but it is quite a lot of money (~$50US) for just the lens hood. It is unfortunate that the lens hood isn't provided with the base product - it is essential.

This is a quick-and-dirty project; a work in progress. It provides flare protection only for the most common - overhead lighting - case. The hood petal was designed by trial and error. It works in the limited situations I tested without interfering with the camera's field of view (nor its sound pickup pattern, as far as I can tell). If you have the wherewithal to develop a hood with more complete and effective coverage, that would be sweet!

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 Filament Spool Holder ClipOn

title: Spool Holder / Tray for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
When I broke my Prusa's original spool holder (which I was never really fond of), I went looking for a replacement and found this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1940105 , designed by Area51. The spool holder is decent, but what really impressed me was the way it clipped on to the Z-frame. Very easy to put on and take off, and rock-solid stable. A great clip design. So i stole it for this Thing.

I've always preferred spool holders that sit on the bench. I've printed several rim-rollers and really like them. But benchtop spool holders really only work well with printers having Bowden or reverse-Bowden filament feed systems. When I got my Prusa, I was stuck with the filament hanging from the Z-frame. I didn't give up, however, I reverse-engineered Area51's design into a chunk of OpenScad and stuck it on these trays in order to be able to reuse my beloved spool holder once again.

This "tray" is remarkably stable - no wiggle, no feeling that it won't hold up - all thanks to Area51's clip design. I plan to make use of it in other Prusa-related things I have floating around in my head.

Enjoy.

description.text:
RPCCS : Raspberry Pi Camera Celestron Support

Project version : V3

This project is to use pi camera on Telescope. This project is design to be print with plastic and/or metal (bearing,nuts, ....). It was also design to be modulable.
The Pi camera used is the version V2.1. It should works with V2.0 and V1.2. Pi camera Noir should works too.
The telescope used is a Celestron Astromaster 90 but should works on other brand.

You are free to improve this project. All source file are downloadable in this project and avalable at thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121976) or github (https://github.com/Inglebard/RPCCS.git).

Software used :

Freecad (with BOLTS http://www.bolts-library.org/fr/index.html)
Cura 2.5

Important :

Some parts fit hardly, you may need some tools for sanding some parts.
I am not an expert on Freecad, so sorry if files are not "clean".
You may use raft if you have some wrapping issue.

Some part are inspired from :

  • @muzz64 (Murray CLARK) : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2237509
  • @mike_mattala (Mike MATTALA) : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

How to print it ? :

All part should be print with 0.1mm, 10% infill is enought. Some part can be replace with metal part but the weight can be an issue if it's not balanced.

Axis can be switch with Axis_alternate but you will be not able to lock the camera on axis with ring support.stl so it's useless to print it in this case.

title: Anet A8 X axis mount with Cable Chain mounty

description.text:
This is still a work in progress, beware. I just installed some Frame stabilizers (thing:2074478). The cable ouput from this is just a little too much to the right and causing a bit of a bind between it and the stabilizer. I'll need to modify it a bit to the left for this to continue working. I may redesign entirely, we'll see.

I've been struggling with my x-axis cable chain. Every workable solution I've found so far pulls the hotend cables out of the main board every time Z goes above a certain point. So, I'm giving this one a shot where I've mixed a cable chain end into the top of the left X mount that msvml submitted and I'll give it a go to see how well it works. I added in a couple of tree type mounts as well since I can't print this one upside down. They stay put and help, but I've uploaded models with and without them.

I know that where the chain is running, I lose a little bit of Z height. So far, I've not had a need to print that high. I'll re-evaluate exactly how I want the chain to run when my need gets there.

The pictures of the piece I printed was an early version. The model has been improved to made the chain end housing lower into the X end and a piece had gotten in the way of the stepper motor. These issues have been fixed in the current model.

description.text:
This is my first design with Tinkercad. I needed something to fit the 38mm hole I drilled into my IKEA Lack table to feed the filament through. I wanted the hole to be a bit bigger to make it possible for the filament to move to the sides a bit when the z axis moves up. Both top an bottom edges are rounded from the inside.
I placed it upside down in my slicer and put some support between build plate and object and used a raft. I did not use supports inside which resulted in a not perfect rounding on the inside, but the effect to smoothen the edge for the filament is still there.
Hope someone finds this useful!

This is my first attempt at printing a multiple part object of this size.  I made this robot for my 5 year old son who's been into robots lately.  I used Pro Engineer for the design.  The robot is 12" tall and took approximately 42 hours to replicate.  The head logo was created using elements from the Nissan logo with a lightning bolt added. The smiley face was inspired by my son's artwork--he likes to draw smiley faces.  The Makerbot logo also doubles as my son's first initial.  This project was a good exercise in figuring out how to orient parts for successful printing.  I'm planning on making smaller simplified versions for office desktop display.

Three computer fans 40x40mm carry a mirror under a small angle with the motor shaft. The beam of a 5 volt laser pen diode hits the first mirror under an angle of 45 degrees. That beam is reflected twice by the two other mirrors. The beam escapes through an opening and projects Lissajous patterns at the wall or ceiling. The speed of the three fans is individually controlled by three 555 PWM circuits allowing to generate math art.
Try to hit the mirrors in the middle. An effective way to adjust is changing the distance of the mirror to the motor by applying some layers of double sided adhesive foam tape between fan and mirror. Or change the thickness of the disk. For that reason the Open SCAD file of the disk is attached.

description.text:
direct replacement for current prusa i3 style x-axis on my original Poltur XL design.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1792378
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1962561

this mod uses a 15x15 tube as appose to 8mm smooth rods typically used.

over the last few days of use it has displayed numerous benefits over the original i3 setup I used.

quieter (so late night prints are a go now)

faster (doesn't suffer with vibes so Ive been able to increase movement speed and reduce overall print times)

smoother operation (has consistently allowed me to produce more and more precise parts)

less wear (use's F608ZZ which are self sealed and self lubricating instead of the LM8UU's typically used in 8mm smooth rod i3 type setups and which suffer with increasing wear and vibrations over time which inturn effect print quality)

can span larger gaps without suffering with flex (8mm smooth rod setups limit just how long a axis you can run as the rods begin to flex if too long which obviously effects Z-height and print quality, the 15x15tube resists flex to a much larger degree)

looks better lol (its matchs the rest of my Poltur design)

the extruder mounts are designed to be quick release (two easy access bolts top and bottom and the mount pulls away from the carriage which makes maintenance incredibly easy without needing to risk upsetting the axis delicate calibration, also assists with extruder type swapping)

3 versions of extruder mount, mk7/8, e3d close range, e3d long range.

uses the same 15x15 alu tubing as the rest of the Poltur frame.

additional (04/03/2017):-

added a centred Mk7/Mk8 extruder mount to allow the extruder the entire use of a 300mm heat bed

description.text:
PT

Aqui está uma possível forma de como construir uns gates para micro drones para fazer corridas indoor (ou outdoor).

É possível tornar os gates maiores ou mais pequenos, cortando maior ou mais pequeno. O que fiz tem 50cm por 50cm.

Material necessário (para um gate):

  • 2 perfis de alumínio 11mmx1mm (diametro x espessura). Estes perfis que tenho têm 1m de comprimento
  • 2x base (com ou sem pesos)
  • 2x conector de 90 graus
  • 2x noodles de natação (opcional, para proteção do drone caso bata no gate)

Base com pesos

Caso optem pela base com pesos, os pesos não são nada mais que chumbos de pesca que podem encontrar na decathlon ( e talvez numa loja de pesca). São pesos de 60g cada um e vem em embalagens de 3

Não têm que ser obrigatóriamente estes pesos - podem comprar mais pequenos e encher os buracos com eles - usando cola quente ou outra cola qualquer

EN

Here's a possible way on how to build a race gate for indoor (or outdoor) micro quad (or not so micro).

You can build them bigger or smaller - all depends on the length of the profiles
Mine here has 50cm by 50cm.

Materials (for one gate)

  • 2 aluminium profiles 11mmx1mm (diameter x thickness). These profiles I bought are 1m in length
  • 2x bases (with or without weights)
  • 2x 90 degrees connector
  • 2x pool noodles (optional, for extra protection if a quad hits the gate)

Base with heights

If you choose this option, the weights are simple fishing sinkers that you can find in any fishing store. These ones are hexagons with 60gr each. You can use others, smaller ones, and just glue them in to the holes

What is it?

This is a mount for my window sill I made for my Egg Shakers, so they don't get lost. It can hold up to 4 egg shakers. The holder is made for sills with a thickness of 21mm. It is easy to adjust that in your 3D-Software.

The parts

The mount is made out of two different parts:

  1. A Stand with 4 holes
  2. A Hanger (two or more needed)

The stand can be used without the hanger for your table. Its dimensions are 20x5x1.5cm
so it's easy to create your own custom holders with these hangers.

Have fun with it! I'm looking forward to see your remixes or prints!

And if you want you can cut the plastic axis of the palm and do the same with an M5 drill.

Voltage regulartor to 6V.

Arduino Nano.

LiPo 2S 7,4V 1000mAh.

description.text:
I created a bracket to mount an optical (z)-endstop on the 2020 extrusion of the Tarantula. The slit is mounted on the nut of a roller of the x-carriage . Because my blue Esun PLA did not block enough light I used a piece of the silver coloured bag the sensor came in and taped it on the slit.

The hight is easy adjustable with one M4 nut. I you want more play for the z-adjustment you can increase the length of the slit.

description.text:
Place a screw or nail in the wall, leaving some of it exposed. Hang the cove molding holder on the screw. You want the holder to be hanging at least 1/4" below where you want the cove molding to end up.

Put up 2-3 of these, then hang your cove molding on the holder. Nail one end in place, then slide the molding holder up and off the screw, and take it out. Leave the screw behind.

Fastcap has a variation of these. You can do a Google search and see how they use them.

remixed_from.author: Simhopp
remixed_from.title: X Motor mount for Anet A8

title: X Motor mount for TronXY P802M

description.text:
I adapted the "X Motor mount for Anet A8 by Simhopp" to fit the dimensions of the TronXY P802M. Changes:

  • Distance between z-axes rods: 17mm
  • Distance between X-axes rods: 44mm
  • Different z-endstop mount
  • Different x-endstop mount

I also changed the x-belt tightener to another design. You need the green part http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2102177, too. Other tighteners for the A8 will not fit because the smaller x-rod distance which forces the belt channel to be smaller, too.

~Note: I have not yet actually assembled my printer with these parts.~

Update: I finally put those into my printer. They actually work. Two minor issues:

  • The z-stop holder is a bit fiddly to get a nut in. Just snip off a bit of the material to make the opening wider. It also is placed a bit too far to the front. That can be fixed easily by putting a thumb-nut onto the end of the screw (counter it with a normal nut).
  • The holes for mounting the x-stop are on the small side. Either widen the hole with a small drill (2mm) or heat up the tip of the screw.

Update 2: I gave up on the integrated z-stop screw mount and am using this one now: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2155010

first tri spinner design I modeled.

Print the Button to switch your favorite hue lights or scenes, homematic scenes or whatelse you can imagine to do with one click esp-01.

After pressing the Button the esp resets and executes the code ( logging into wlan, searching for bridge, sending data). After that the esp goes into deepsleep again and wait for the next reset. The deep sleep mode don't need much energy so you can use the Button for a long time without changing batteries ( I hope so ;) )

I use it for my lights to switch a good morning scene (lights, coffeemachine) and for some all off buttons.

I used @PrintMo 's Rugged Lens Filter Case locking system for the button
( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:415961 )

How it works: https://youtu.be/y_RpBIn9FNE

BOM

print all the parts
buy the electronics
2x 10k resistor
1x 3mm LED (+resistor for the LED) in my case 150Ohm
1x perfboard 6*19 dots
2x battery holders (AAA)
2x 4 pin connectors
1x micro push button (long)
1x M4 nut and screw
2x 5mm Neodym magnets
double sided tape
maybe some small springs
1x esp-01

wire the Electronic

on the picture:
1- 10k resistor
2 - 150Ohm
left side the esp-01 bottom view (means VCC is in upper left corner, GND in lower right)
the hole on the left is for a M4 screw

Hint for battery saving

some ESP-01 boards have a working red power LED.

"Note: Some batches of this module ship with LED Current limiting resistors of the wrong value (47Ohm vs 4.7KOhm). This usually results in the power LED vanishing in a puff of smoke. "
http://www.esp8266.com/wiki/doku.php?id=esp8266-module-family#esp-01

For our project that fact is good cause we save some power ;)
If the red LED is not destroyed on your board ... destroy it. The LED is also glowing in deep sleep mode so it's draining our battery. I powered mine then I saw where the red LED is located and used a plier to destroy it.

Build the Button and insert electronic
place the M4 nut to secure the electronic
the magnets are for holding it in place (cut the support on the bottom to place them)
the holes in the base are for some tiny springs. Look in your local hardware store for some

All instructions are in the video too.

you can use the attached .ino file as a start
some examples for hue lights are in.
From start to action the button needs about 5 secs
maybe you can reduce the time by using static ip adresses

description.text:
Hook for hanging tools and wire loops. I also printed some in white to hold a razor in the shower.

Uses double-sided tape to hold it in place.
While you can use any double-sided tape, the absolute best is 3M VHB Clear tape. You can find it here:
http://amzn.to/2mci0GO

I've used the gray version, and it doesn't work as well. I've also tried various other double-sided carpet tapes, and they all eventually fail.

Final note: make sure you clean the plastic with rubbing alcohol before applying the tape. If there is any oil on the plastic it will cause the tape adhesive to fail eventually.

Stir Plate for homebrew yeast starters. My other thing, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:198838, used a 12V fan I couldn't get to go slow enough, even with a PWM Controller. So I made on to work a typical motor. You can modify the dxf to work with whatever size motor you have. My motor was 1.4" in diameter, and slightly over 3 inches long. It has a mount for the PWM Controller: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009HKFAIQ/ref=oh_details_o03_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 It used magnets from: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001ANVAHI/ref=oh_details_o04_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

description.text:
This is a flux syringe cap.
It's interior cavity is slightly conical, so it'll snugly fit a classic "Amtech RMA-223 (clone)" flux tube.
As it's an OpenSCAD, it can be easily modified to fit another kind of dispenser.
The 4 main parameters to change would be:
ID1 and ID2 relative to H1: These are two diameters to be measured at a distance of H1 on the collar of the dispenser (see pictures).
IntLen : This is the length between the ID1 measuring point on the collar and the tip of the dispensing needle (add some leeway here).

You can also change the wall width (WW) but don't go too far...

The plunger used in the pictures is from Divinecobra: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1902471
